stream_context.summary: Kaze fixes a major collision bug (wall clipping) and continues building Overworld Part 3, focusing on designing the lighthouse as a small interior challenge that triggers a rotating light/cutscene and unlocks progression (clearing a fog barrier and opening the next world). He also discusses playtesting workflow (single-person test ROMs), scope control, toolchain dependencies (Fast64/Zelda-hacker tooling), asset/texture pipeline, planned localization, crediting rules, and the project’s long-term goal of replacing remaining original SM64 code for a fully custom codebase and safer release as a patch.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains multiple documentary-relevant decisions: open-world/no-warp philosophy, lighthouse gating design that unlocks a world, explicit plan to reach “0% Mario 64 code” for safety/ownership, a concrete intro storyboard from Biobak, and clear process notes on beta testing and scope management.

findings.summary: Kaze fixed a severe collision bug that let Mario move through walls (a floating-point error in wall collision), previously visible as the Wario clipping bug and especially abusable for speed in a Koopa-the-Quick context.

Overworld structure is being built as a connected, circular open world: Part 3 loops back to earlier areas at a higher elevation, with future physical traversal elements (e.g., a spool you kick down) instead of obvious warp travel.
findings.quote: There’s gonna be no warps in the final game. It’s all just gonna be actually an open world.

findings.summary: Although the game will still have loading zones, Kaze wants to hide transitions so they feel seamless (no warp transition; at most a frame or two of visible startup), leveraging short R64 loading times.

The lighthouse is designed as an overworld puzzle hub: entering it and hitting a switch rotates the lighthouse light to point toward a ship and, crucially, disables a fog “warp-out” barrier so the player can pass through and unlock a new level/world.

Kaze debated making the lighthouse interior purely a switch room, but decided it likely needs a short challenge so players feel they “earned” the unlock and remember the action; he leans toward a walljump-focused mini-level with a mostly static camera anchored around the lighthouse center.

Kaze’s iteration loop includes isolating individual levels into a separate test ROM and sending it to a single tester for focused feedback before wider polishing; he notes his audience/fame makes recruiting testers easier than for most indie devs.
He frames his current production approach as: finish rough first versions of levels, beta test, then polish—preferring momentum and feedback cycles over perfecting content in isolation.

Kaze explicitly intends to remove remaining original SM64 code before release, aiming for “0% Mario 64 code,” both to better match his own coding standards and for safety/ownership; he also reiterates release as a patch “to be safe.”
findings.quote: Eventually we’ll be at 0% Mario 64 code.

findings.summary: The intro sequence is being developed with a storyboard/cinematic concept made by Biobak: Mario receives a letter about Yoshis being captured; Kaze acknowledges the story tone is darker than typical Mario but wants antagonist Bozo framed as a ruthless capitalist who enslaves Yoshis in factories.
Localization is anticipated: Kaze expects at least a German version by himself, with Biobak interested in French and Rionna in Spanish (Kaze indicates he won’t personally produce all languages).

Kaze described his memory/engine constraints and custom allocator philosophy: he largely avoids deallocation and is already concerned about potentially running out of memory in dense overworld areas as assets increase.

Kaze states a concrete crediting threshold: contributors are credited if an asset or something that actually ships makes it into the game; he resists credit inflation for vague encouragement or trivial ideas.

biobak.summary: Biobak created a storyboard/cinematic concept for a revised intro: Mario at home receives a letter explaining Dinosaurland is in danger and Yoshis were captured; it’s positioned as the new intro (replacing an older one).
Kaze says Biobak is working on the Ice Cap area/level (key progression gate tied to the treasure-map/message-in-a-bottle hint chain).
Kaze suspects Biobak has been less active recently because he’s working on a different project, which Kaze treats as acceptable.
Kaze describes Biobak’s texture-style approach: often building a 3D model and pre-rendering it into a texture; some textures also come from Minecraft texture packs.

zeina.summary: Zeina made a crib asset intended for Course 9; it functions as a warp interaction (Mario jumps into it), themed as a baby Yoshi crib.
Kaze plans to ask Zeina to model a setpiece/prop for the overworld where Wario sells the player a star (tied to a 1000-coin transaction after beating Wario).
Kaze recounts he helped Zeina on a past art test (cleaning up a model), implying he supported her hiring process.

findings.summary: Graham offered to create improved tiling textures for the lighthouse and later to help with stylized overworld landmark meshes/textures; Kaze hopes this will replace his placeholder/ugly textures and better communicate the intended look.
Kaze says Rionna wants to make a Spanish localization version.

key_stories.title: Fixing the wall-clipping collision bug
key_stories.summary: Kaze opens by describing a severe bug where Mario could pass through walls due to floating-point issues in wall collision. It was the same root issue as the Wario clipping behavior and had major gameplay implications, including easy speed gain in a Koopa-the-Quick scenario.
key_stories.challenge: Unreliable/incorrect 3D collision created unintended exploits and broke basic traversal rules.
key_stories.process: He tracked the issue to a floating-point error in wall collision and applied a fix, noting that collision fixes frequently introduce new collision bugs.
key_stories.outcome: The no-clip behavior is fixed for now, restoring expected collision boundaries and reducing speed/exploit routes.

key_stories.title: Designing the lighthouse as a world-unlock puzzle
key_stories.summary: Kaze defines the lighthouse’s gameplay purpose: a small interior sequence culminating in a switch that rotates the lighthouse light toward a ship and clears a fog barrier that previously warped the player out. He debates how much challenge is needed so the action feels memorable and earned.
key_stories.challenge: Make an overworld puzzle that meaningfully signals progression (unlocking a new area/world) without becoming a frustrating camera-tight platforming segment.
key_stories.process: He explores interior layout options, considers a static/centered camera, and settles on a walljump-themed mini-challenge leading up to the switch, plus a cutscene/rotation event.
key_stories.outcome: Clear direction: implement a lighthouse interior walljump challenge, then the switch triggers a rotation/cutscene and opens the next world; remaining tasks include final textures, camera tuning, and the fog-clear mechanic.

key_stories.title: Replacing original SM64 code to reach a safer, more ‘ownable’ game
key_stories.summary: Kaze states he has already removed additional pieces of original SM64 code and wants to reach a point where no original code remains. He frames this as both a quality refactor (aligning with his own guidelines) and part of shipping responsibly (as a patch) while making room for non-Mario player characters in other projects.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing a ROM-hack heritage with the desire to build something that is structurally closer to an original game and less dependent on Nintendo’s legacy code.
key_stories.process: Incrementally ripping out SM64 remnants, planning a pre-release audit to remove remaining leftovers, and refactoring systems (e.g., audio code already heavily simplified).
key_stories.outcome: A stated project goal of “0% Mario 64 code,” reinforcing the documentary theme of deconstructing a classic to rebuild a new game on old hardware constraints.
key_stories.key_quote: Eventually we’ll be at 0% Mario 64 code.

open_questions.topic: Lighthouse fog barrier and light-rotation unlock implementation
open_questions.context: Kaze describes the lighthouse switch rotating the light to shine into a foggy area; after that, the player can pass through the fog without being warped out, effectively unlocking progression/world access.
questions: How exactly is the fog ‘warp-out’ enforced today (trigger volume, distance check, camera rule), and what will the switch change (flag, object behavior swap, area reload)?
How will the rotating light be presented: real dynamic light, animated texture/vertex colors, or a cutscene-driven visual trick?
What player feedback will confirm the unlock (sound cue, camera pan, cutaway to ship/fog clearing, UI text)?

open_questions.topic: Open-world feel vs hidden loading zones
open_questions.context: Kaze says there will be loading zones but no visible warp transitions; at most, a frame or two of ‘startup’ so the world feels seamless.
questions: What is the technical approach for hiding transitions (preload, black-frame suppression, camera hold, or micro-stutter acceptance)?
What constraints (RAM, geometry budget, segmented levels) force these loading seams, and where are they most likely to appear?
How will you prevent players from noticing/abusing seam boundaries for speed or clipping?

open_questions.topic: Ice Cap discovery chain and player guidance
open_questions.context: Progression appears to depend on players finding and completing Ice Cap; Kaze worries it must be obvious and fast to find. He shifts from a ‘randomly appears later’ plan to placing an immediate, sparkling message-in-a-bottle that gives landmark-based instructions.
questions: What changed your mind from ‘random appearance’ to ‘immediate message-in-bottle’—was it tester confusion, pacing, or dependency with other worlds?
What is the final intended instruction language so it’s precise but not obscure (backflips/ground-pound vs other unambiguous inputs)?
Will there be redundancy (multiple hints, NPCs, visual landmarks) so players who don’t know advanced moves still discover Ice Cap?

open_questions.topic: Reconciling ‘Mario stays’ with the goal of ‘0% Mario 64 code’
open_questions.context: Kaze says RTYI will keep Mario, but also emphasizes removing all original SM64 code for safety/ownership and mentions replacing Mario with a custom character for a separate game.
questions: What does ‘0% Mario 64 code’ mean in practice for RTYI—engine/runtime code only, or also assets/animations?
If Mario remains playable, what is the legal/ethical boundary you’re drawing (patch-only distribution, original code removed, original assets handled how)?
What parts are still ‘SM64 remnants’ you most want gone before release (collision, camera, audio, object behaviors)?

open_questions.context: Biobak’s intro storyboard frames a darker premise (mass capture/enslavement of Yoshis). Kaze wants Bozo characterized as a ruthless capitalist exploiting Yoshis for factories/ships.
questions: How do you want players to feel in the opening—comedic villainy, serious stakes, or a mix?
What guardrails keep the story ‘Mario-like’ while still supporting the exploitation/factory theme?
How will the intro be implemented in-engine (pre-render, in-game cutscene, text + panels), and who owns which parts of production?
